argumentText:
Let $p_n=\prod_{i=1}^n u_i$. We have to study the convergence of the
sequence $\{p_n\}$. The sequence $\{p_n\}$ converges to a not null limit
iff $\{\log p_n\}$ ($\log$ is restricted to its principal branch)
converges to a finite limit. By the Cauchy criterion, this happens iff
for every $\epsilon^{\prime}>0$ there exist $N$ such that
${\left\vert\log
p_{n+k} - \log p_n\right\vert} < \epsilon^{\prime}$ for all $n>N$ and
all $k=1,2,\ldots$, i.e, iff
$${\left\vert\log \frac{p_{n+k}}{p_n}\right\vert} = {\left\vert\log u_{n+1}u_{n+2}\cdots u_{n+k}\right\vert} < \epsilon^{\prime};$$
as $\log(z)$ is an injective function and continuous at $z=1$ and
$\log(1)=0$ this will happen iff for every $\epsilon>0$
$${\left\vertu_{n+1}u_{n+2}\cdots u_{n+k}-1\right\vert} < \epsilon$$ for
$n$ greater than $N$ and $k=1,2,\ldots$
names: proof of convergence condition of infinite product
